repnme.cdata!:
Cape Verde - Education and Training
            Consolidation and Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, including satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. Notwithstanding,
            lessons of experience outline, and are suggested as follows.
            It is reinforced that policy dialogue between the Borrower
            and the Bank requires flexibility, particularly when dealing
            with the evolving educational context. Specifically, the
            Bank responsiveness to the Borrower's needs was prompt,
            misunderstandings were timely reduced, all of which
            conducive to mutual confidence. In the context of sector
            reforms, the Government's political commitment was
            critical to the Project success: reforms were pursued in the
            basic education, and professional training sector with
            support being provided from across two ruling parties.
            However, the integration of the Project Unit (PCU) into the
            regular structure of the Ministry of Education (MOE)
            required capacity-building, and a good communication
            strategy, implemented through a gradual process. The prior
            assessment of the PCU capacity was crucial to ensure the
            success of school construction programs.

repnme.cdata!:
Cape Verde - Education and Training
            Consolidation and Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education and Training Consolidation
            and Modernization Project extends the Basic Education and
            Training Project (report no. 13568). This project aims to a)
            maintain and consolidate the recent reforms in primary
            education and in demand-driven training and apprenticeship
            programs initiated under the earlier project; and b) assist
            the government of Cape Verde in carrying out a comprehensive
            sector study, addressing issues of quality and equity, in
            order to identify cost-effective options for the sustainable
            development of the education/training system (ETS) through
            the medium term. The project also provides the underpinnings
            for a human resource development program which the
            Government intends to launch in 2001. The project has four
            components. The first reinforces the integration of basic
            education by improving primary school infrastructure and
            increasing textbook supply and teacher guides; and
            reinforces training and apprenticeship programs,
            strengthening the sector's policy and advisory bodies
            and improving the quality and efficiency of employment
            surveys and job placement services. The second component
            funds a qualitative assessment of education subsectors. The
            third component supports field-testing of selected options;
            and supports consultation, information, and communication.
            The fourth component builds the capacity of the education
            and the employment and training ministries.
